title: Stock Futures Waver as Economy Falters; Results are due after the close from Apple, Amazon and Intel
text:
The U.S. economy shrank at a 0.9% annual rate last quarter, marking a second straight quarterly decline in gross domestic product, the Commerce Department said Thursday.

While the data showed the economy is in a worse state than expected, investors would likely not rush to make any new bets on whether it will alter the Fed's plan for interest rates, said Hani Redha, a portfolio manager at PineBridge Investments.

"There can often be this 'bad news is good news' idea," he said. "But for the Fed, fighting inflation is still the priority."

Stock markets have started the third quarter in better form than the declines seen in the first half of the year. Corporate earnings haven't been as bad as investors had feared, suggesting that soaring inflation and signs of flagging economic growth aren't weighing too heavily on companies' balance sheets.

Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve has signaled it is serious about bringing inflation down. On Wednesday it raised its federal-funds rate by 0.75 percentage point to a range between 2.25% and 2.5%.

Investors are looking to earnings figures from major blue-chip and technology companies Thursday for guidance. Tech giants Amazon and Apple are due to report earnings after markets close.

Ahead of the opening bell, Facebook-parent Meta Platforms fell 4.5% after reporting its first decline in revenue after hours Wednesday. Qualcomm declined 2.6% after issuing a muted sales outlook. Ford jumped 6.6% after reporting a 50% rise in revenue. Online marketplace operator Etsy gained 6.4% after it reported better-than-expected results.

Spirit Airlines shares were up 2.2% premarket after JetBlue Airways agreed to buy the carrier. The deal came after The Wall Street Journal reported that the two sides were close to sealing an agreement following a monthslong bidding war between JetBlue and Frontier Group Holdings. JetBlue shares rose 0.7%.

Honeywell International rose 2.5% while Harley-Davidson jumped 6.3% after both reported better-than-expected earnings.

Southwest Airlines fell 6.1% after issuing mixed guidance and a warning about inflationary headwinds. Comcast slumped 7.8% after it failed to gain broadband subscribers during the latest quarter.

Despite recent gains for major indexes, investors remain concerned about stretched valuations and the pace of Fed rate rises. Many aren't ready to jump back into the market.

"The rally we have seen looks like a classic bear market rally, rather than the launch of a new bull market," said David Donabedian, chief investment officer of CIBC Private Wealth US. "We are still going to have a period where inflation is uncomfortably high and growth is uncomfortably low and that is not a good backdrop."

In bond markets, the yield on the benchmark 10-Year U.S. Treasury note rose to 2.785% from 2.731% on Wednesday. The yield on the 2-year note rose to 2.980% from 2.968%.

The WSJ Dollar Index, which tracks the greenback against a basket of peer currencies, rose 0.2%.

In commodity markets, Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, rose 1.5% to $103.22 a barrel. Gold prices gained 1.1%.

Overseas, European indexes were broadly higher. The pan-continental Stoxx Europe 600 rose 0.6%, led by its mining stocks while telecommunication companies lost ground. Barclays shares fell more than 3% after saying its profits nearly halved in the second quarter after a bond-sale mistake.

In Asia, stock markets were mixed. Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.4%, while in China the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.2%. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong weakened 0.2%.

Write to Will Horner at william.horner@wsj.com
